newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian lending rate down to 9.8 pct from 10.9.
newsitem.headline: Croatian lending rate down to 9.8 pct from 10.9.

text.p: The Croatian average lending rate fell to 9.8 percent on Thursday from 10.9 percent amid abundant offers and high bank liquidity, dealers said.
Daily trade totalled 37.6 million kuna, against 132 million kuna on offer. One bank sought another 3.4 million kuna but failed to agree on terms with lenders.
Fresh borrowing accounted for 24.6 million kuna, of which call money loans amounted to 17.5 million. They were granted at eight percent, down from Wednesday's 8.5 percent.
One two-week loan and a one-month borrowing were struck at 13 percent.
Insurers rolled over previous loans at nine percent for one-week and 13.5 percent for one-month borrowings.
Banks charged 10, 12 and 13 percent for old one-week, 20-day and 3-day loans, respectively.
The central bank calculated its kuna midrates for Friday weaker at 6.1571 against the dollar and firmer at 3.5681 against the mark. -- Zoran Radosavljevic, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
